admin@338.Name: admin@338
admin@338.Description: admin@338 is a China-based cyber threat group. It has previously used newsworthy events as lures to deliver malware and has primarily targeted organizations involved in financial, economic, and trade policy, typically using publicly available RATs such as PoisonIvy, as well as some non-public backdoors. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: admin@338 actors used the following commands following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to enumerate user accounts: net user >> %temp%\download net user /domain >> %temp%\download[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Following exploitation with LOWBALL malware, admin@338 actors created a file containing a list of commands to be executed on the compromised computer.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: admin@338 actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with LOWBALL malware to obtain information about files and directories: dir c:\ >> %temp%\download dir "c:\Documents and Settings" >> %temp%\download dir "c:\Program Files\" >> %temp%\download dir d:\ >> %temp%\download[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: admin@338 actors used the following command to rename one of their tools to a benign file name: ren "%temp%\upload" audiodg.exe[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: admin@338 actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to list local groups: net localgroup administrator >> %temp%\download[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: admin@338 actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with LOWBALL malware to obtain information about the OS: ver >> %temp%\download systeminfo >> %temp%\download[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: admin@338 actors used the following command after exploiting a machine with LOWBALL malware to acquire information about local networks: ipconfig /all >> %temp%\download[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: admin@338 actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to display network connections: netstat -ano >> %temp%\download[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: admin@338 actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with LOWBALL malware to obtain information about services: net start >> %temp%\download[1]

APT1.Name: APT1
APT1.Description: APT1 is a Chinese threat group that has been attributed to the 2nd Bureau of the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) General Staff Department’s (GSD) 3rd Department, commonly known by its Military Unit Cover Designator (MUCD) as Unit 61398. [1]
APT1.Aliases: APT1, Comment Crew, Comment Group, Comment Panda

Techniques Used.Name: Acquire and/or use 3rd party software services
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 used third party email services in the registration of whois records.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Compromise 3rd party infrastructure to support delivery
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 hijacked FQDNs associated with legitimate websites hosted by hop points. Mandiant considers them to be “hijacked” since they were originally registered for a legitimate reason but were used by APT1 for malicious purposes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Compromise 3rd party infrastructure to support delivery
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 comrpomised a vast set of 3rd party victim hop points as part of their network infrastructure.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Domain registration hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 hijacked FQDNs associated with legitimate websites hosted by hop points. Mandiant considers them to be “hijacked” since they were originally registered for a legitimate reason but are used by APT1 for malicious purposes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Dynamic DNS
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 used dynamic DNS to register hundreds of FQDNs.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obtain/re-use payloads
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 used publicly available privilege escalation tools.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 has used the Windows command shell to execute commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 has been known to use credential dumping.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 has used RAR to compress files before moving them outside of the victim network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 has collected files from a local victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 uses two utilities, GETMAIL and MAPIGET, to steal email. GETMAIL extracts emails from archived Outlook .pst files, and MAPIGET steals email still on Exchange servers that has not yet been archived.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: The file name AcroRD32.exe, a legitimate process name for Adobe's Acrobat Reader, was used by APT1 as a name for malware.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Hash
Techniques Used.Use: The APT1 group is known to have used pass the hash.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The APT1 group is known to have used RDP during operations.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: APT1 has used batch scripting to automate execution of commands.[1]

APT17.Name: APT17
APT17.Description: APT17 is a China-based threat group that has conducted network intrusions against U.S. government entities, the defense industry, law firms, information technology companies, mining companies, and non-government organizations. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Build social network persona
Techniques Used.Use: APT17 posted in forum threads and created profile pages in Microsoft TechNet.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Develop social network persona digital footprint
Techniques Used.Use: APT17 created biographical sections on TechNet profile pages to appear more legitimate.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscate infrastructure
Techniques Used.Use: APT17 obfuscated infrastructure using a multi-layered malware beaconing approach. [1]

APT18.Name: APT18
APT18.Description: APT18 is a threat group that has operated since at least 2009 and has targeted a range of industries, including technology, manufacturing, human rights groups, government, and medical. [1]
APT18.Aliases: APT18, TG-0416, Dynamite Panda, Threat Group-0416

Techniques Used.Use: APT18 actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: APT18 actors used the native at Windows task scheduler tool to use scheduled tasks for execution on a victim network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: APT18 actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.[2]

APT19.Name: APT19
APT19.Description: APT19 is a Chinese-based threat group that has targeted a variety of industries, including defense, finance, energy, pharmaceutical, telecommunications, high tech, education, manufacturing, and legal services. In 2017, a phishing campaign was used to target seven law and investment firms. [1] Some analysts track APT19 and Deep Panda as the same group, but it is unclear from open source information if the groups are the same. [2] [3] [4]
APT19.Aliases: APT19, Codoso, C0d0so0, Codoso Team, Sunshop Group

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 used TCP port 80 for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: An APT19 HTTP malware variant used Base64 to encode communications to the C2 server.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: An APT19 HTTP malware variant decrypts strings using single-byte XOR keys.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 launched an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant using a legitimate executable that loaded the malicious DLL.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 performed a watering hole attack on forbes.com in 2014 to compromise targets.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Existing Service
Techniques Used.Use: An APT19 Port 22 malware variant registers itself as a service.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 uses a Port 22 malware variant to modify several Registry keys.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 used Base64 to obfuscate commands and the payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 used PowerShell commands to execute payloads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: An APT19 HTTP malware variant establishes persistence by setting the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Windows Debug Tools-%LOCALAPPDATA%\.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Regsvr32
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 used Regsvr32 to bypass application whitelisting techniques.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 configured its payload to inject into the rundll32.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 downloaded and launched code within a SCT file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments in RTF and XLSM formats to deliver initial exploits.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 used HTTP for C2 communications. APT19 also used an HTTP malware variant to communicate over HTTP for C2.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 collected system architecture information. APT19 used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to gather the hostname and CPU information from the victim’s machine.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to collect the MAC address and IP address from the victim’s machine.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 used an HTTP malware variant and a Port 22 malware variant to collect the victim’s username.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: APT19 attempted to get users to launch malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.[1]

APT28.Name: APT28
APT28.Description: APT28 is a threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Main Intelligence Directorate of the Russian General Staff by a July 2018 U.S. Department of Justice indictment. This group reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8] [9]
APT28.Aliases: APT28, Sednit, Sofacy, Pawn Storm, Fancy Bear, STRONTIUM, Tsar Team, Threat Group-4127, TG-4127

Techniques Used.Name: Buy domain name
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 registered domains imitating NATO and OSCE security websites and Caucasus information resources.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Obtain/re-use payloads
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 reused the SOURFACE downloader as the payload of a lure document.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used CVE-2015-1701 to access the SYSTEM token and copy it into the current process as part of privilege escalation.[11]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 used a publicly available tool to gather and compress multiple documents on the DCCC and DNC networks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bootkit
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has deployed a bootkit along with Downdelph to ensure its persistence on the victim. The bootkit shares code with some variants of BlackEnergy.[12]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 uses cmd.exe to execute commands.[9]

Techniques Used.Name: Communication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 uses a tool that captures information from air-gapped computers via an infected USB and transfers it to network-connected computer when the USB is inserted.[13]

Techniques Used.Name: Component Object Model Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used COM hijacking for persistence by replacing the legitimate MMDeviceEnumerator object with a payload.[14]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 used other victims as proxies to relay command traffic, for instance using a compromised Georgian military email server as a hop point to NATO victims. The group has also used a tool that acts as a proxy to allow C2 even if the victim is behind a router. APT28 has also used a machine to relay and obscure communications between CHOPSTICK and their server.[4][15][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 regularly deploys both publicly available and custom password retrieval tools on victims.[16][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 used a publicly available tool to gather and compress multiple documents on the DCCC and DNC networks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Information Repositories
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has collected information from Microsoft SharePoint services within target networks.[17]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has retrieved internal documents from machines inside victim environments, including by using Forfiles to stage documents before.[18][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: An APT28 backdoor may collect the entire contents of an inserted USB device.[13]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 added "junk data" to each encoded string, preventing trivial decoding without knowledge of the junk removal algorithm. Each implant was given a "junk length" value when created, tracked by the controller software to allow seamless communication but prevent analysis of the command protocol on the wire.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has stored captured credential information in a file named pi.log.[13]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: An APT28 macro uses the command certutil -decode to decode contents of a .txt file storing the base64 encoded payload.[19][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has delivered JHUHUGIT and Koadic by executing PowerShell commands through DDE in Word documents.[20][21][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has collected emails from victim Microsoft Exchange servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Defense Evasion
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used CVE-2015-4902 to bypass security features.[15][13]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used CVE-2014-4076, CVE-2015-2387, and CVE-2015-1701 to escalate privileges.[15][13]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation of Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 exploited a Windows SMB Remote Code Execution Vulnerability to conduct lateral movement.[4][22][23]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used Forfiles to locate PDF, Excel, and Word documents during. The group also searched a compromised DCCC computer for specific terms.[18][1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has intentionally deleted computer files to cover their tracks, including with use of the program CCleaner.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Techniques Used.Use: An APT28 loader Trojan saves its payload with hidden file attributes.[24]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has cleared event logs, including by using the commands wevtutil cl System and wevtutil cl Security.[3][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used tools to perform keylogging.[13][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Logon Scripts
Techniques Used.Use: An APT28 loader Trojan adds the Registry key HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript to establish persistence.[24]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Sniffing
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 deployed the open source tool Responder to conduct NetBIOS Name Service poisoning, which captured usernames and hashed passwords that allowed access to legitimate credentials.[4][22]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 encrypted a .dll payload using RTL and a custom encryption algorithm. APT28 has also obfuscated payloads with base64, XOR, and RC4.[15][19][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Office Application Startup
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used the Office Test persistence mechanism within Microsoft Office by adding the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Office test\Special\Perf to execute code.[25]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Hash
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used pass the hash for lateral movement.[13]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 uses a module to receive a notification every time a USB mass storage device is inserted into a victim.[13]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 downloads and executes PowerShell scripts.[9]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: An APT28 loader Trojan will enumerate the victim's processes searching for explorer.exe if its current process does not have necessary permissions.[24]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has downloaded additional files, including by using a first-stage downloader to contact the C2 server to obtain the second-stage implant.[15][24]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 uses a tool to infect connected USB devices and transmit itself to air-gapped computers when the infected USB device is inserted.[13]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 executed CHOPSTICK by using rundll32 commands such as rundll32.exe “C:\Windows\twain_64.dll”. APT28 also executed a .dll for a first stage dropper using rundll32.exe. An APT28 loader Trojan saved a batch script that uses rundll32 to execute a DLL payload.[3][15][9][24]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used tools to take screenshots from victims.[16][26][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: An APT28 loader Trojan uses a batch script to run its payload.[24]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 sent spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Office attachments.[19][8][9][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 sent spearphishing emails which used a URL-shortener service to masquerade as a legitimate service and to redirect targets to credential harvesting sites.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 used SMTP as a communication channel in various implants, initially using self-registered Google Mail accounts and later compromised email servers of its victims. Later implants such as CHOPSTICK use a blend of HTTP and other legitimate channels, depending on module configuration.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has performed timestomping on victim files.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Trusted Relationship
Techniques Used.Use: Once APT28 gained access to the DCCC network, the group then proceeded to use that access to compromise the DNC network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 attempted to get users to click on Microsoft Excel attachments containing malicious macro scripts.[19]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: APT28 has used legitimate credentials to maintain access to a victim network and exfiltrate data. The group also used credentials stolen through a spearphishing email to login to the DCCC network.[27][1]

APT29.Name: APT29
APT29.Description: APT29 is threat group that has been attributed to the Russian government and has operated since at least 2008. [1] [2] This group reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015. [3]
APT29.Aliases: APT29, The Dukes, Cozy Bear, CozyDuke

Techniques Used.Name: Accessibility Features
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 used sticky-keys to obtain unauthenticated, privileged console access.[4][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 has bypassed UAC.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Domain Fronting
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 has used the meek domain fronting plugin for Tor to hide the destination of C2 traffic.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 has used multiple software exploits for common client software, like Microsoft Word and Adobe Reader, to gain code execution as part of.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 used SDelete to remove artifacts from victims.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Multi-hop Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: A backdoor used by APT29 created a Tor hidden service to forward traffic from the Tor client to local ports 3389 (RDP), 139 (Netbios), and 445 (SMB) enabling full remote access from outside the network.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Hash
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 used Kerberos ticket attacks for lateral movement.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 has used encoded PowerShell scripts uploaded to CozyCar installations to download and install SeaDuke. APT29 also used PowerShell scripts to evade defenses.[6][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 added Registry Run keys to establish persistence.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 used named and hijacked scheduled tasks to establish persistence.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 has used encoded PowerShell scripts uploaded to CozyCar installations to download and install SeaDuke, as well as to evade defenses.[6][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 used UPX to pack files.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 has used spearphishing with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 has used spearphishing with a link to trick victims into clicking on a link to a zip file containing malicious files.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 has used various forms of spearphishing attempting to get a user to open links or attachments.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 used WMI to steal credentials and execute backdoors at a future time.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Techniques Used.Use: APT29 has used WMI event filters to establish persistence.[4]

APT3.Name: APT3
APT3.Description:
APT3 is a China-based threat group that researchers have attributed to China's Ministry of State Security. [1] [2] This group is responsible for the campaigns known as Operation Clandestine Fox, Operation Clandestine Wolf, and Operation Double Tap. [1] [3] As of June 2015, the group appears to have shifted from targeting primarily US victims to primarily political organizations in Hong Kong. [4]
APT3 Adversary Emulation Plan - [5]
APT3.Aliases: APT3, Gothic Panda, Pirpi, UPS Team, Buckeye, Threat Group-0110, TG-0110

Techniques Used.Name: Accessibility Features
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 replaces the Sticky Keys binary C:\Windows\System32\sethc.exe for persistence.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has used a tool that can obtain info about local and global group users, power users, and administrators.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has been known to add created accounts to local admin groups to maintain elevated access.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Brute Force
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has been known to brute force password hashes to be able to leverage plain text credentials.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: An APT3 downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe" /C whoami. The group also uses a tool to execute commands on remote computers.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 uses commonly used ports (like HTTPS/443) for command and control.[7]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: An APT3 downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has been known to create or enable accounts, such as support_388945a0.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has used a tool to dump credentials by injecting itself into lsass.exe and triggering with the argument "dig." The group has also used a tools to dump passwords from browsers.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Credentials in Files
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that can locate credentials in files on the file system such as those from Firefox or Chrome.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has used tools to compress data before exfilling it.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 will identify Microsoft Office documents on the victim's computer.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has been known to stage files for exfiltration in a single location.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has been known to side load DLLs with a valid version of Chrome with one of their tools.[8][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that exfiltrates data over the C2 channel.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that looks for files and directories on the local file system.[8][7]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that can delete files.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Graphical User Interface
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has interacted with compromised systems to browse and copy files through its graphical user interface in Remote Desktop Protocol sessions.[10]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has been known to remove indicators of compromise from tools.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has used a keylogging tool that records keystrokes in encrypted files.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Multi-Stage Channels
Techniques Used.Use: An APT3 downloader first establishes a SOCKS5 connection to 192.157.198[.]103 using TCP port 1913; once the server response is verified, it then requests a connection to 192.184.60[.]229 on TCP port 81.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that creates a new service for persistence.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 obfuscates files or information to help evade defensive measures.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that can enumerate the permissions associated with Windows groups.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that can list out currently running processes.[8][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Redundant Access
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has been known to use multiple backdoors per campaign.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 places scripts in the startup folder for persistence.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 enables the Remote Desktop Protocol for persistence.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that can copy files to remote machines.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that can detect the existence of remote systems.[4][8]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that can run DLLs.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: An APT3 downloader creates persistence by creating the following scheduled task: schtasks /create /tn "mysc" /tr C:\Users\Public\test.exe /sc ONLOGON /ru "System".[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has been known to pack their tools.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: An APT3 downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that can obtain information about the local system.[4][7]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A keylogging tool used by APT3 gathers network information from the victim, including the MAC address, IP address, WINS, DHCP server, and gateway.[4][7]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 has a tool that can enumerate current network connections.[4][8][7]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: An APT3 downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe" /C whoami to verify that it is running with the elevated privileges of “System.”[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: An APT3 downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections to two separate IP addresses over TCP port 1913 and TCP port 81.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 leverages valid accounts after gaining credentials for use within the victim domain.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: APT3 will copy files over to Windows Admin Shares (like ADMIN$) as part of lateral movement.[4]

APT32.Name: APT32
APT32.Description:
APT32 is a threat group that has been active since at least 2014. The group has targeted multiple private sector industries as well as with foreign governments, dissidents, and journalists with a strong focus on Southeast Asian countries like Vietnam, Phillipines, Laos, and Cambodia. They have extensively used strategic web compromises to compromise victims. 
The group is believed to be Vietnam-based. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Deployment Software
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 compromised McAfee ePO to move laterally by distributing malware as a software deployment task.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 includes garbage code to mislead anti-malware software and researchers.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 uses Cobalt Strike's malleable C2 functionality to blend in with network traffic.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 ran genuinely-signed executables from Symantec and McAfee which loaded a malicious DLL called rastls.dll.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has used CVE-2016-7255 to escalate privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has cleared select event log entries.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has used hidden or non-printing characters to help masquerade file names on a system, such as appending a Unicode no-break space character to a legitimate service name.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 creates a Windows service to establish persistence.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 uses the Invoke-Obfuscation framework to obfuscate their PowerShell and also performs other code obfuscation.[1][5][3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has used PowerShell-based tools and shellcode loaders for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Regsvr32
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 created a Scheduled Task that used regsvr32.exe to execute a COM scriptlet that dynamically downloaded a backdoor and injected it into memory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has added JavaScript to victim websites to download additional frameworks that profile and compromise website visitors.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has used scheduled tasks to persist on victim systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Signed Script Proxy Execution
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has used PubPrn.vbs within execution scripts to execute malware, possibly bypassing defenses.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 sends emails to victims with a malicious executable disguised as a document or spreadsheet displaying a fake icon.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has used JavaScript that communicates over HTTP or HTTPS to attacker controlled domains to download additional frameworks.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 collects the OS version and computer name.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 collects the victim's username.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has used scheduled task raw XML with a backdated timestamp of June 2, 2016.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has attempted to lure users to execute a malicious dropper delivered via a spearphishing attachment.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has used legitimate local admin account credentials.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Shell
Techniques Used.Use: APT32 has used Web shells to maintain access to victim websites.[2]

APT33.Name: APT33
APT33.Description: APT33 is a suspected Iranian threat group that has carried out operations since at least 2013. The group has targeted organizations across multiple industries in the United States, Saudi Arabia, and South Korea, with a particular interest in the aviation and energy sectors. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: APT33 sent spear phishing emails containing links to .hta files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: APT33 has lured users to click links to malicious HTML applications delivered via spearphishing emails.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: APT33 has used valid accounts for privilege escalation.[2]

APT37.Name: APT37
APT37.Description: APT37 is a suspected North Korean cyber espionage group that has been active since at least 2012. The group has targeted victims primarily in South Korea, but also in Japan, Vietnam, Russia, Nepal, China, India, Romania, Kuwait, and other parts of the Middle East. APT37 has also been linked to following campaigns between 2016-2018: Operation Daybreak, Operation Erebus, Golden Time, Evil New Year, Are you Happy?, FreeMilk, Northern Korean Human Rights, and Evil New Year 2018. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Audio Capture
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has used an audio capturing utility known as SOUNDWAVE that captures microphone input.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has signed its malware with an invalid digital certificates listed as “Tencent Technology (Shenzhen) Company Limited.”[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has used the command-line interface.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has used port 8080 for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has used a credential stealer known as ZUMKONG that can harvest usernames and passwords stored in browsers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 credential stealer ZUMKONG emails credentials from the victim using HTTP POST requests.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has collected data from victims' local systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has used strategic web compromises, particularly of South Korean websites, to distribute malware. The group has also used torrent file-sharing sites to more indiscriminately disseminate malware to victims. As part of their compromises, the group has used a Javascript based profiler called RICECURRY to profile a victim's web browser and deliver malicious code accordingly.[2][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has used Windows DDE for execution of commands and a malicious VBS.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 leverages the Windows API calls: VirtualAlloc(), WriteProcessMemory(), and CreateRemoteThread() for process injection.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has used Flash Player (CVE-2016-4117, CVE-2018-4878) and Word (CVE-2017-0199) exploits for execution.[2][1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has access to destructive malware that is capable of overwriting a machine's Master Boot Record (MBR).[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 sends images to users that are embedded with shellcode and obfuscates strings and payloads.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT37's Freenki malware lists running processes using the Microsoft Windows API.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 injects its malware variant, ROKRAT, into the cmd.exe process.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: APT37's has added persistence via the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has downloaded second stage malware from compromised websites.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 executes shellcode and a script to decode Base64 strings.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 delivers malware using spearphishing emails with malicious HWP attachments.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 uses HTTPS to conceal C2 communications.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 collects the computer name, the BIOS model, and execution path.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 identifies the victim username.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 has sent spearphishing attachments attempting to get a user to open them.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: APT37 leverages social networking sites and cloud platforms (AOL, Twitter, Yandex, Mediafire, pCloud, Dropbox, and Box) for C2.[1][3]

Axiom.Name: Axiom
Axiom.Description: Axiom is a cyber espionage group suspected to be associated with the Chinese government. It is responsible for the Operation SMN campaign. [1] Though both this group and Winnti Group use the malware Winnti, the two groups appear to be distinct based on differences in reporting on the groups' TTPs and targeting. [2] [3] [4]

Techniques Used.Name: Accessibility Features
Techniques Used.Use: Axiom actors have been known to use the Sticky Keys replacement within RDP sessions to obtain persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Axiom has been known to dump credentials.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Obfuscation
Techniques Used.Use: The Axiom group has used other forms of obfuscation, include commingling legitimate traffic with communications traffic so that network streams appear legitimate. Some malware that has been used by Axiom also uses steganography to hide communication in PNG image files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
Techniques Used.Use: Axiom has been observed using SQL injection to gain access to systems.[1][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: The Axiom group is known to have used RDP during operations.[1]

BlackOasis.Name: BlackOasis
BlackOasis.Description: BlackOasis is a Middle Eastern threat group that is believed to be a customer of Gamma Group. The group has shown interest in prominent figures in the United Nations, as well as opposition bloggers, activists, regional news correspondents, and think tanks. [1] [2] A group known by Microsoft as NEODYMIUM is reportedly associated closely with BlackOasis operations, but evidence that the group names are aliases has not been identified. [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: BlackOasis's first stage shellcode contains a NOP sled with alternative instructions that was likely designed to bypass antivirus tools.[1]

BRONZE BUTLER.Name: BRONZE BUTLER
BRONZE BUTLER.Description: BRONZE BUTLER is a cyber espionage group with likely Chinese origins that has been active since at least 2008. The group primarily targets Japanese organizations, particularly those in government, biotechnology, electronics manufacturing, and industrial chemistry. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used net user /domain to identify account information.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER downloader code has included "0" characters at the end of the file to inflate the file size in a likely attempt to evade anti-virus detection.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER malware xxmm contains a UAC bypass tool for privilege escalation.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER uses the command-line interface.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used various tools to perform credential dumping.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used a tool called RarStar that encodes data with a custom XOR algorithm when posting it to a C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has compressed data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Several BRONZE BUTLER tools encode data with base64 when posting it to a C2 server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has compressed and encrypted data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has exfiltrated files stolen from local systems.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Network Shared Drive
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has exfiltrated files stolen from file shares.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER downloads encoded payloads and decodes them on the victim.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER compromised three Japanese websites using a Flash exploit to perform watering hole attacks.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has exploited Microsoft Word vulnerability CVE-2014-4114 for execution.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has collected a list of files from the victim and uploaded it to its C2 server, and then created a new list of specific files to steal.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: The BRONZE BUTLER uploader or malware the uploader uses command to delete the RAR archives after they have been exfiltrated.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has given malware the same name as an existing file on the file share server to cause users to unwittingly launch and install the malware on additional systems.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Ticket
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has created forged Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) and Ticket Granting Service (TGS) tickets to maintain administrative access.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used PowerShell for execution.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used a batch script that adds a Registry Run key to establish malware persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used various tools to download files, including DGet (a similar tool to wget).[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER typically use ping and Net to enumerate systems.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used at and schtasks to register a scheduled task to execute malware during lateral movement.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used a tool to capture screenshots.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used VBS, VBE, and batch scripts for execution.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER used spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to infect victims.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER malware has used HTTP for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used RC4 encryption (for Datper malware) and AES (for xxmm malware) to obfuscate HTTP traffic.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has used net time to check the local time on a target system.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER has attempted to get users to launch malicious Microsoft Word attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: BRONZE BUTLER's MSGET downloader uses a dead drop resolver to access malicious payloads.[2]

Carbanak.Name: Carbanak
Carbanak.Description: Carbanak is a threat group that mainly targets banks. It also refers to malware of the same name (Carbanak). It is sometimes referred to as FIN7, but these appear to be two groups using the same Carbanak malware and are therefore tracked separately. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak may use netsh to add local firewall rule exceptions.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak malware names itself "svchost.exe," which is the name of the Windows shared service host program.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak malware installs itself as a service to provide persistence and SYSTEM privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Access Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak used legitimate programs such as AmmyAdmin and Team Viewer for remote interactive C2 to target systems.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak installs VNC server software that executes through rundll32.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak actors used legitimate credentials of banking employees to perform operations that sent them millions of dollars.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: Carbanak has used a VBScript named "ggldr" that uses Google Apps Script, Sheets, and Forms services for C2.[4]

Charming Kitten.Name: Charming Kitten
Charming Kitten.Description: Charming Kitten is an Iranian cyber espionage group that has been active since approximately 2014. They appear to focus on targeting individuals of interest to Iran who work in academic research, human rights, and media, with most victims having been located in Iran, the US, Israel, and the UK. Charming Kitten usually tries to access private email and Facebook accounts, and sometimes establishes a foothold on victim computers as a secondary objective. The group's TTPs overlap extensively with another group, Rocket Kitten, resulting in reporting that may not distinguish between the two groups' activities. [1]

Software.Name: DownPaper
Software.Techniques: Command-Line Interface, PowerShell, Query Registry, Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder, Standard Application Layer Protocol, System Information Discovery, System Owner/User Discovery

Cleaver.Name: Cleaver
Cleaver.Description: Cleaver is a threat group that has been attributed to Iranian actors and is responsible for activity tracked as Operation Cleaver. [1] Strong circumstantial evidence suggests Cleaver is linked to Threat Group 2889 (TG-2889). [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Build social network persona
Techniques Used.Use: Cleaver created fake LinkedIn profiles.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Create custom payloads
Techniques Used.Use: Cleaver has created customized tools and payloads for functions including ARP poisoning, encryption, credential dumping, ASP.NET shells, web backdoors, process enumeration, WMI querying, HTTP and SMB communications, network interface sniffing, and keystroke logging.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Develop social network persona digital footprint
Techniques Used.Use: Cleaver's fake personas included profile photos, details, and network connections.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscation or cryptography
Techniques Used.Use: Cleaver has used zhCat to encrypt traffic or use inline obfuscation to make detection more difficult. zhCat makes message traffic look benign.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Cleaver has been known to dump credentials.[1]

Software.Techniques: Account Manipulation, Credential Dumping, Credentials in Files, DCShadow, Pass the Hash, Pass the Ticket, Private Keys, Security Support Provider, SID-History Injection

Software.Techniques: Brute Force, Credential Dumping, Service Execution, Windows Admin Shares

Cobalt Group.Name: Cobalt Group
Cobalt Group.Description: Cobalt Group is a financially motivated threat group that has primarily targeted financial institutions. The group has conducted intrusions to steal money via targeting ATM systems, card processing, payment systems and SWIFT systems. Cobalt Group has mainly targeted banks in Eastern Europe, Central Asia, and Southeast Asia. One of the alleged leaders was arrested in Spain in early 2018, but the group still appears to be active. The group has been known to target organizations in order to use their access to then compromise additional victims. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] Reporting indicates there may be links between Cobalt Group and both the malware Carbanak and the group Carbanak. [8]
Cobalt Group.Aliases: Cobalt Group, Cobalt Gang, Cobalt Spider

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has bypassed UAC.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: CMSTP
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has used the command cmstp.exe /s /ns C:\Users\ADMINI~W\AppData\Local\Temp\XKNqbpzl.txt to bypass AppLocker and launch a malicious script.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has sent malicious Word OLE compound documents to victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group had exploited multiple vulnerabilities for execution, including Microsoft’s Equation Editor (CVE-2017-11882), an Internet Explorer vulnerability (CVE-2018-8174), CVE-2017-8570, and CVE-2017-0199.[1][2][3][5][6][7][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has used exploits to increase their levels of rights and privileges.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group deleted the DLL dropper from the victim’s machine to cover their tracks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group leveraged an open-source tool called SoftPerfect Network Scanner to perform network scanning.[2][3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has created new services to establish persistence.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group obfuscated several scriptlets and code used on the victim’s machine, including through use of XOR.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has used powershell.exe to download and execute scripts.[1][2][3][4][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has injected code into trusted processes.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Redundant Access
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has used TeamViewer to preserve remote access in case control using the Cobalt Strike module was lost.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has used Registry Run keys for persistence. The group has also set a Startup path to launch the PowerShell shell command and download Cobalt Strike.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Regsvr32
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group used regsvr32.exe to execute scripts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Access Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group used the Ammyy Admin tool as well as TeamViewer for remote access.[2][3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has used Remote Desktop Protocol to conduct lateral movement.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group uses public sites such as github.com and sendspace.com to upload files and then download them to victim computers.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has created Windows tasks to establish persistence.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has sent Word OLE compound documents with malicious obfuscated VBA macros that will run upon user execution. The group has also used an exploit toolkit known as Threadkit that launches .bat files.[1][2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has sent spearphishing emails with various attachment types to corporate and personal email accounts of victim organizations. Attachment types have included .rtf, .doc, .xls, archives containing LNK files, and password protected archives containing .exe and .scr executables.[1][2][3][4][5][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has sent emails with URLs pointing to malicious documents.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has used HTTPS and DNS tunneling for C2. The group has also used the Plink utility to create SSH tunnels.[1][3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has used the Plink utility to create SSH tunnels.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group has sent emails containing malicious attachments or links that require users to execute a file or macro to infect the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: XSL Script Processing
Techniques Used.Use: Cobalt Group used msxsl.exe to bypass AppLocker and to invoke Jscript code from an XSL file.[1]

CopyKittens.Name: CopyKittens
CopyKittens.Description: CopyKittens is an Iranian cyber espionage group that has been operating since at least 2013. It has targeted countries including Israel, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, the U.S., Jordan, and Germany. The group is responsible for the campaign known as Operation Wilted Tulip. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: CopyKittens digitally signed an executable with a stolen certificate from legitimate company AI Squared.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: CopyKittens uses ZPP, a .NET console program, to compress files with ZIP.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: CopyKittens encrypts data with a substitute cipher prior to exfiltration.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: CopyKittens has used PowerShell Empire.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Rundll32
Techniques Used.Use: CopyKittens uses rundll32 to load various tools on victims, including a lateral movement tool named Vminst, Cobalt Strike, and shellcode.[2]

Dark Caracal.Name: Dark Caracal
Dark Caracal.Description: Dark Caracal is threat group that has been attributed to the Lebanese General Directorate of General Security (GDGS) and has operated since at least 2012. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Compiled HTML File
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal leveraged a compiled HTML file that contained a command to download and run an executable.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal collected complete contents of the 'Pictures' folder from compromised Windows systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal leveraged a watering hole to serve up malicious code.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal collected file listings of all default Windows directories.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal has obfuscated strings in Bandook by base64 encoding, and then encrypting them.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal's version of Bandook adds a registry key to HKEY_USERS\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run for persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal took screen shots using their Windows malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal has used macros in Word documents that would download a second stage if executed.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal has used UPX to pack Bandook[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing via Service
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal spearphished victims via Facebook and Whatsapp.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal's version of Bandook communicates with their server over a TCP port using HTTP payloads Base64 encoded and suffixed with the string “&&&”[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Dark Caracal makes their malware look like Flash Player, Office, or PDF documents in order to entice a user to click on it.[1]

Darkhotel.Name: Darkhotel
Darkhotel.Description: Darkhotel is a threat group that has been active since at least 2004. The group has conducted activity on hotel and business center Wi‑Fi and physical connections as well as peer-to-peer and file sharing networks. The actors have also conducted spearphishing. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Darkhotel has used code-signing certificates on its malware that are either forged due to weak keys or stolen.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Darkhotel uses a sophisticated keylogger.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Darkhotel has been known to establish persistence by adding programs to the Run Registry key.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Replication Through Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: Darkhotel's selective infector modifies executables stored on removable media as a method of spreading across computers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Taint Shared Content
Techniques Used.Use: Darkhotel uses a virus that propagates by infecting executables stored on shared drives.[1]

DarkHydrus.Name: DarkHydrus
DarkHydrus.Description: DarkHydrus is a threat group that has targeted government agencies and educational institutions in the Middle East since at least 2016. The group heavily leverages open-source tools and custom payloads for carrying out attacks. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Forced Authentication
Techniques Used.Use: DarkHydrus used Template Injection to launch an authentication window for users to enter their credentials.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: DarkHydrus leveraged PowerShell to download and execute additional scripts for execution.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: DarkHydrus has sent spearphishing emails with password-protected RAR archives containing malicious Excel Web Query files (.iqy). The group has also sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office documents that use the “attachedTemplate” technique to load a template from a remote server.[1][3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Template Injection
Techniques Used.Use: DarkHydrus used an open-source tool, Phishery, to inject malicious remote template URLs into Microsoft Word documents and then sent them to victims to enable Forced Authentication.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: DarkHydrus has sent malware that required users to hit the enable button in Microsoft Excel to allow an .iqy file to be downloaded.[1][2]

Deep Panda.Name: Deep Panda
Deep Panda.Description: Deep Panda is a suspected Chinese threat group known to target many industries, including government, defense, financial, and telecommunications. [1] The intrusion into healthcare company Anthem has been attributed to Deep Panda. [2] This group is also known as Shell Crew, WebMasters, KungFu Kittens, and PinkPanther. [3] Deep Panda also appears to be known as Black Vine based on the attribution of both group names to the Anthem intrusion. [4] Some analysts track Deep Panda and APT19 as the same group, but it is unclear from open source information if the groups are the same. [5]
Deep Panda.Aliases: Deep Panda, Shell Crew, WebMasters, KungFu Kittens, PinkPanther, Black Vine

Techniques Used.Name: Accessibility Features
Techniques Used.Use: Deep Panda has used the sticky-keys technique to bypass the RDP login screen on remote systems during intrusions.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Deep Panda has updated and modified its malware, resulting in different hash values that evade detection.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Deep Panda has used PowerShell scripts to download and execute programs in memory, without writing to disk.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Deep Panda uses the Microsoft Tasklist utility to list processes running on systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Regsvr32
Techniques Used.Use: Deep Panda has used regsvr32.exe to execute a server variant of Derusbi in victim networks.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Deep Panda has used ping to identify other machines of interest.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Deep Panda has used PowerShell scripts to download and execute programs in memory, without writing to disk.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Shell
Techniques Used.Use: Deep Panda uses Web shells on publicly accessible Web servers to access victim networks.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Deep Panda uses net.exe to connect to network shares using net use commands with compromised credentials.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: The Deep Panda group is known to utilize WMI for lateral movement.[1]

Dragonfly.Name: Dragonfly
Dragonfly.Description:
Dragonfly is a cyber espionage group that has been active since at least 2011. They initially targeted defense and aviation companies but shifted to focus on the energy sector in early 2013. They have also targeted companies related to industrial control systems. [1]
A similar group emerged in 2015 and was identified by Symantec as Dragonfly 2.0. There is debate over the extent of the overlap between Dragonfly and Dragonfly 2.0, but there is sufficient evidence to lead to these being tracked as two separate groups. [2] [3]

Software.Name: Backdoor.Oldrea
Software.Techniques: Credential Dumping, Data Encrypted, Data Obfuscation, Email Collection, File and Directory Discovery, File Deletion, Process Discovery, Process Injection, Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder, System Information Discovery, System Network Configuration Discovery, System Owner/User Discovery

Software.Techniques: Credential Dumping, Data Staged, Process Discovery, Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder, Remote File Copy, Screen Capture, Software Packing

Dragonfly 2.0.Name: Dragonfly 2.0
Dragonfly 2.0.Description: Dragonfly 2.0 is a suspected Russian group that has targeted government entities and multiple U.S. critical infrastructure sectors since at least March 2016. [1] [2] There is debate over the extent of overlap between Dragonfly 2.0 and Dragonfly, but there is sufficient evidence to lead to these being tracked as two separate groups. [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used batch scripts to enumerate users in the victim environment.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 added newly created accounts to the administrators group to maintain elevated access.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Brute Force
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 dropped and executed tools used for password cracking, including Hydra.[1][4][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used command line for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used SMB over ports 445 or 139 for C2. The group also established encrypted connections over port 443.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 created accounts on victims, including administrator accounts, some of which appeared to be tailored to each individual staging target.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 dropped and executed SecretsDump and CrackMapExec, tools that can dump password hashes.[1][4][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 compressed data into .zip files prior to exfiltrating it.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 collected data from local victim systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 created a directory named "out" in the user's %AppData% folder and copied files to it.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 has disabled host-based firewalls. The group has also globally opened port 3389.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 compromised legitimate organizations' websites to create watering holes to compromise victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 accessed email accounts using Outlook Web Access.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: External Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used VPNs and Outlook Web Access (OWA) to maintain access to victim networks.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used a batch script to gather folder and file names from victim hosts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 deleted many of its files used during operations as part of cleanup, including removing applications and deleting screenshots.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Forced Authentication
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 has gathered hashed user credentials over SMB using spearphishing attachments with external resource links and by modifying .LNK file icon resources to collect credentials from virtualized systems.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 cleared Windows event logs and other logs produced by tools they used, including system, security, terminal services, remote services, and audit logs. The actors also deleted specific Registry keys.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 created accounts disguised as legitimate backup and service accounts as well as an email administration account.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 modified the Registry to perform multiple techniques through the use of Reg.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 identified and browsed file servers in the victim network, sometimes , viewing files pertaining to ICS or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used batch scripts to enumerate administrators in the environment.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used PowerShell scripts for execution.[1][2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 queried the Registry to identify victim information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 added the registry value ntdll to the Registry Run key to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 moved laterally via RDP.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 copied and installed tools for operations once in the victim environment.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 likely obtained a list of hosts in the victim environment.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used scheduled tasks to automatically log out of created accounts every 8 hours as well as to execute malicious files.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 has performed screen captures of victims, including by using a tool, scr.exe (which matched the hash of ScreenUtil).[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used various types of scripting to perform operations, including Python and batch scripts. The group was observed installing Python 2.7 on a victim.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 manipulated .lnk files to gather user credentials in conjunction with Forced Authentication.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used spearphishing with Microsoft Office attachments to target victims.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used spearphishing with PDF attachments containing malicious links that redirected to credential harvesting websites.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used SMB for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used batch scripts to enumerate network information, including information about trusts, zones, and the domain.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 used the command query user on victim hosts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Template Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 has injected SMB URLs into malicious Word spearphishing attachments to initiate Forced Authentication.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 has used various forms of spearphishing in attempts to get users to open links or attachments.[1][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 compromised user credentials and used valid accounts for operations.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Shell
Techniques Used.Use: Dragonfly 2.0 commonly created Web shells on victims' publicly accessible email and web servers, which they used to maintain access to a victim network and download additional malicious files.[1][4]

DragonOK.Name: DragonOK
DragonOK.Description: DragonOK is a threat group that has targeted Japanese organizations with phishing emails. Due to overlapping TTPs, including similar custom tools, DragonOK is thought to have a direct or indirect relationship with the threat group Moafee. [1] It is known to use a variety of malware, including Sysget/HelloBridge, PlugX, PoisonIvy, FormerFirstRat, NFlog, and NewCT. [2]

Dust Storm.Name: Dust Storm
Dust Storm.Description: Dust Storm is a threat group that has targeted multiple industries in Japan, South Korea, the United States, Europe, and several Southeast Asian countries. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Dust Storm has used Android backdoors capable of exfiltrating specific files directly from the infected devices.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Dust Storm has used Android backdoors capable of enumerating specific files on the infected devices.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Dust Storm has encoded payloads with a single-byte XOR, both skipping the key itself and zeroing in an attempt to avoid exposing the key.[1]

Elderwood.Name: Elderwood
Elderwood.Description: Elderwood is a suspected Chinese cyber espionage group that was reportedly responsible for the 2009 Google intrusion known as Operation Aurora. [1] The group has targeted defense organizations, supply chain manufacturers, human rights and nongovernmental organizations (NGOs), and IT service providers. [2] [3]
Elderwood.Aliases: Elderwood, Elderwood Gang, Beijing Group, Sneaky Panda

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims by injecting malicious code into specific public Web pages visited by targets within a particular sector.[2][3][1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Elderwood has used exploitation of endpoint software, including Microsoft Internet Explorer Adobe Flash vulnerabilities, to gain execution. They have also used zero-day exploits.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Elderwood has encrypted documents and malicious executables.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: The Ritsol backdoor trojan used by Elderwood can download files onto a compromised host from a remote location.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: Elderwood has packed malware payloads before delivery to victims.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing malicious attachments.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing a link to malicious content hosted on an uncommon Web server.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Supply Chain Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Elderwood has targeted manufacturers in the supply chain for the defense industry.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Elderwood has leveraged multiple types of spearphishing in order to attempt to get a user to open links and attachments.[2][3]
