Equation.Name: Equation
Equation.Description: Equation is a sophisticated threat group that employs multiple remote access tools. The group is known to use zero-day exploits and has developed the capability to overwrite the firmware of hard disk drives. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Component Firmware
Techniques Used.Use: Equation is known to have the capability to overwrite the firmware on hard drives from some manufacturers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Equation has used tools with the functionality to search for specific information about the attached hard drive that could be used to identify and overwrite the firmware.[1]

FIN10.Name: FIN10
FIN10.Description: FIN10 is a financially motivated threat group that has targeted organizations in North America since at least 2013 through 2016. The group uses stolen data exfiltrated from victims to extort organizations. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: FIN10 has used batch scripts and scheduled tasks to delete critical system files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: FIN10 uses PowerShell for execution as well as PowerShell Empire to establish persistence.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: FIN10 has established persistence by using the Registry option in PowerShell Empire to add a Run key.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FIN10 has used RDP to move laterally to systems in the victim environment.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: FIN10 has deployed Meterpreter stagers and SplinterRAT instances in the victim network after moving laterally.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: FIN10 has established persistence by using S4U tasks as well as the Scheduled Task option in PowerShell Empire.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: FIN10 has executed malicious .bat files containing PowerShell commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FIN10 has used Meterpreter to enumerate users on remote systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: FIN10 has used stolen credentials to connect remotely to victim networks using VPNs protected with only a single factor. The group has also moved laterally using the Local Administrator account.[1]

FIN5.Name: FIN5
FIN5.Description: FIN5 is a financially motivated threat group that has targeted personally identifiable information and payment card information. The group has been active since at least 2008 and has targeted the restaurant, gaming, and hotel industries. The group is made up of actors who likely speak Russian. [1] [2] [3]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 has dumped credentials from victims. Specifically, the group has used the tool GET5 Penetrator to look for remote login and hard-coded credentials.[3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 scripts save memory dump data into a specific directory on hosts in the victim environment.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: External Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 has used legitimate VPN, RDP, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.[1][3][2]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 uses SDelete to clean up the environment and attempt to prevent detection.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 has cleared event logs from victims.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Redundant Access
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 maintains access to victim environments by using Valid Accounts to access External Remote Services as well as establishing a backup RDP tunnel by using FLIPSIDE.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 has used the open source tool Essential NetTools to map the network and build a list of targets.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: FIN5 has used legitimate VPN, RDP, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.[1][3][2]

FIN6.Name: FIN6
FIN6.Description: FIN6 is a cyber crime group that has stolen payment card data and sold it for profit on underground marketplaces. This group has aggressively targeted and compromised point of sale (PoS) systems in the hospitality and retail sectors. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 has used Metasploit’s PsExec NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 has used a script to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 has used Windows Credential Editor for credential dumping, as well as Metasploit’s PsExec NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Following data collection, FIN6 has compressed log files into a ZIP archive prior to staging and exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: TRINITY malware used by FIN6 encodes data gathered from the victim with a simple substitution cipher and single-byte XOR using the OxAA key.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: TRINITY malware used by FIN6 identifies payment card track data on the victim and then copies it to a local file in a subdirectory of C:\Windows\. Once the malware collects the data, FIN6 actors compressed data and moved it to another staging system before exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 has used tools to exploit Windows vulnerabilities in order to escalate privileges. The tools targeted CVE-2013-3660, CVE-2011-2005, and CVE-2010-4398, all of which could allow local users to access kernel-level privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 has used a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 has used Registry Run keys to establish persistence for its downloader tools known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 used RDP to move laterally in victim networks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 used publicly available tools (including Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool, osql.exe) to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance against Active Directory, Structured Query Language (SQL) servers, and NetBIOS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence for various malware it uses, including downloaders known as HARDTACK and SHIPBREAD and PoS malware known as TRINITY.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 has used a Metasploit PowerShell module to download and execute shellcode and to set up a local listener. FIN6 has also used scripting to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy data to a log file, and remove the original data files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FIN6 used the Plink command-line utility to create SSH tunnels to C2 servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: To move laterally on a victim network, FIN6 has used credentials stolen from various systems on which it gathered usernames and password hashes.[1]

Software.Techniques: Service Execution, Windows Admin Shares

Software.Techniques: Credential Dumping

FIN7.Name: FIN7
FIN7.Description: FIN7 is a financially-motivated threat group that has primarily targeted the U.S. retail, restaurant, and hospitality sectors since mid-2015. They often use point-of-sale malware. A portion of FIN7 was run out of a front company called Combi Security. FIN7 is sometimes referred to as Carbanak Group, but these appear to be two groups using the same Carbanak malware and are therefore tracked separately. [1] [2] [3] [4]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Shimming
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 has used application shim databases for persistence.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 has signed Carbanak payloads with legally purchased code signing certificates. FIN7 has also digitally signed their phishing documents, backdoors and other staging tools to bypass security controls.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 used cmd.exe to launch commands on the victim’s machine.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 has used ports 53, 80, 443, and 8080 for C2.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 spear phishing campaigns have included malicious Word documents with DDE execution.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 has created a scheduled task named “AdobeFlashSync” to establish persistence.[7]

Techniques Used.Name: Mshta
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 has used mshta.exe to execute VBScript to execute malicious code on victim systems.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 created new Windows services and added them to the startup directories for persistence.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 has used fragmented strings, environment variables, standard input (stdin), and native character-replacement functionalities to obfuscate commands.[8][4]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 uses a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieves an additional payload.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 malware has created Registry Run and RunOnce keys to establish persistence, and has also added items to the Startup folder.[2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 has downloaded additional malware to execute on the victim's machine, including by using a PowerShell script to launch shellcode that retrieves an additional payload.[2][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 malware has created scheduled tasks to establish persistence.[2][7][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 captured screenshots and desktop video recordings.[9]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 used VBS and JavaScript scripts to help perform tasks on the victim's machine.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 created several .LNK files on the victim's machine.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 sent spearphishing emails with either malicious Microsoft Documents or RTF files attached.[2][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 has performed C2 using DNS via A, OPT, and TXT records.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 lured victims to double-click on images in the attachments they sent which would then execute the hidden LNK file.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Video Capture
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 created a custom video recording capability that could be used to monitor operations in the victim's environment.[4][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: FIN7 used legitimate services like Google Docs, Google Scripts, and Pastebin for C2.[4]

FIN8.Name: FIN8
FIN8.Description: FIN8 is a financially motivated threat group known to launch tailored spearphishing campaigns targeting the retail, restaurant, and hospitality industries. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 executes commands remotely via cmd.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has tunneled RDP backdoors over port 443.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 harvests credentials using Invoke-Mimikatz or Windows Credentials Editor (WCE).[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has used RAR to compress collected data before.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 aggregates staged data from a network into a single location.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has used FTP to exfiltrate collected data.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has exploited the CVE-2016-0167 local vulnerability.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has deleted tmp and prefetch files during post compromise cleanup activities.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal on Host
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has cleared logs during post compromise cleanup activities.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has deleted Registry keys during post compromise cleanup activities.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has used environment variables and standard input (stdin) to obfuscate command-line arguments. FIN8 also obfuscates malicious macros delivered as payloads.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8's malicious spearphishing payloads are executed as PowerShell. FIN8 has also used PowerShell during and.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has used RDP for.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has used remote code execution to download subsequent payloads.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 uses dsquery and other Active Directory utilities to enumerate hosts.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has used scheduled tasks to maintain RDP backdoors.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has used a Batch file to automate frequently executed post compromise cleanup activities.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has used Registry keys to detect and avoid executing in potential sandboxes.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has distributed targeted emails containing Word documents with embedded malicious macros.[1][2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has distributed targeted emails containing links to malicious documents with embedded macros.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has used the Plink utility to tunnel RDP back to C2 infrastructure.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has leveraged both Spearphishing Link and Spearphishing Attachment attempting to gain User Execution.[1][2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has utilized Valid Accounts during and.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8 has attempted to map to C$ on enumerated hosts to test the scope of their current credentials/context.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: FIN8's malicious spearphishing payloads use WMI to launch malware and spawn cmd.exe execution. FIN8 has also used WMIC during and post compromise cleanup activities.[1][3]

Gamaredon Group.Name: Gamaredon Group
Gamaredon Group.Description: Gamaredon Group is a threat group that has been active since at least 2013 and has targeted individuals likely involved in the Ukrainian government. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Removable Media
Techniques Used.Use: A Gamaredon Group file stealer has the capability to steal data from newly connected logical volumes on a system, including USB drives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: A Gamaredon Group file stealer transfers collected files to a hardcoded C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Gamaredon Group tools contained an application to check performance of USB flash drives.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Tools used by Gamaredon Group are capable of downloading and executing additional payloads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Gamaredon Group has used various batch scripts to establish C2, download additional files, and conduct other functions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: A Gamaredon Group file stealer can communicate over HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A Gamaredon Group file stealer can gather the victim's computer name and drive serial numbers to send to a C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A Gamaredon Group file stealer can gather the victim's username to send to a C2 server.[1]

Software.Name: Pteranodon
Software.Techniques: Command-Line Interface, Data Staged, Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel, File and Directory Discovery, File Deletion, Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder, Remote File Copy, Rundll32, Scheduled Task, Screen Capture, Standard Application Layer Protocol

GCMAN.Name: GCMAN
GCMAN.Description: GCMAN is a threat group that focuses on targeting banks for the purpose of transferring money to e-currency services. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: GCMAN uses Putty and VNC for lateral movement.[1]

Gorgon Group.Name: Gorgon Group
Gorgon Group.Description: Gorgon Group is a threat group consisting of members who are suspected to be Pakistan-based or have other connections to Pakistan. The group has performed a mix of criminal and targeted attacks, including campaigns against government organizations in the United Kingdom, Spain, Russia, and the United States. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can use cmd.exe to download and execute payloads and to execute commands on the system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can decode contents from a payload that was Base64 encoded and write the contents to a file.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can attempt to disable security features in Microsoft Office and Windows Defender using the taskkill command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Execution through API
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can leverage the Windows API call, CreateProcessA(), for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can deactivate security mechanisms in Microsoft Office by editing several keys and values under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Office\.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can use PowerShell commands to download and execute a payload and open a decoy document on the victim’s machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can use process hollowing to inject one of its trojans into another process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can download a remote access tool, NanoCore, and inject into another process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can create a .lnk file and add a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can download additional files from C2 servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group has used macros in Spearphishing Attachments as well as executed VBScripts on victim machines.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group malware can create a .lnk file and add a Registry Run key to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group sent emails to victims with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group has used a variant of NanoCore RAT that communicates with its C2 server over port 6666.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Gorgon Group attempted to get users to launch malicious Microsoft Office attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.[1]

Software.Name: QuasarRAT
Software.Techniques: Code Signing, Command-Line Interface, Connection Proxy, Credential Dumping, Credentials in Files, Input Capture, Masquerading, Modify Registry, Remote Desktop Protocol, Remote File Copy, Scheduled Task, Standard Cryptographic Protocol, System Information Discovery, Video Capture

Group5.Name: Group5
Group5.Description: Group5 is a threat group with a suspected Iranian nexus, though this attribution is not definite. The group has targeted individuals connected to the Syrian opposition via spearphishing and watering holes, normally using Syrian and Iranian themes. Group5 has used two commonly available remote access tools (RATs), njRAT and NanoCore, as well as an Android RAT, DroidJack. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Malware used by Group5 is capable of remotely deleting files from victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Malware used by Group5 is capable of capturing keystrokes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Group5 disguised its malicious binaries with several layers of obfuscation, including encrypting the files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Malware used by Group5 is capable of watching the victim's screen.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: Group5 packed an executable by base64 encoding the PE file and breaking it up into numerous lines.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Group5 C2 servers communicated with malware over TCP 8081, 8282, and 8083.[1]

Honeybee.Name: Honeybee
Honeybee.Description: Honeybee is a campaign led by an unknown actor that targets humanitarian aid organizations and has been active in Vietnam, Singapore, Argentina, Japans, Indonesia, and Canada. It has been an active operation since August of 2017 and as recently as February 2018. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: AppCert DLLs
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee's service-based DLL implant can execute a downloaded file with parameters specified using CreateProcessAsUser.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Exfiltration
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee performs data exfiltration is accomplished through the following command-line command: from  (- --).txt.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee uses a combination of NTWDBLIB.dll and cliconfg.exe to bypass UAC protections using DLL hijacking.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee uses a dropper called MaoCheng that harvests a stolen digital signature from Adobe Systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Several commands are supported by the Honeybee's implant via the command-line interface and there’s also a utility to execute any custom command on an infected endpoint.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee collects data from the local victim system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee drops a Word file containing a Base64-encoded file in it that is read, decoded, and dropped to the disk by the macro.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee's service-based DLL implant traverses the FTP server’s directories looking for files with keyword matches for computer names or certain keywords.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee removes batch files to reduce fingerprint on the system as well as deletes the CAB file that gets encoded upon infection.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Existing Service
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee has batch files that modify the system service COMSysApp to load a malicious DLL.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee uses a batch file that modifies Registry keys to launch a DLL into the svchost.exe process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee drops files with base64-encoded data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee gathers a list of processes using the tasklist command and then is sent back to the control server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee uses a batch file to load a DLL into the svchost.exe process.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee uses a batch file that configures the ComSysApp service to autostart in order to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee embeds a Visual Basic script within a malicious Word document as part of initial access; the script is executed when the Word document is opened. The actors also used batch scripting.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee launches a DLL file that gets executed as a service using svchost.exe[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee uses FTP for command and control.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Honeybee gathers computer name and information using the systeminfo command.[1]

Ke3chang.Name: Ke3chang
Ke3chang.Description:
Ke3chang is a threat group attributed to actors operating out of China.
Ke3chang has targeted several industries, including oil, government, military, and more. [1] [2] [3]
Ke3chang.Aliases: Ke3chang, APT15, Mirage, Vixen Panda, GREF, Playful Dragon, RoyalAPT

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang performs account discovery using commands such as net localgroup administrators and net group "REDACTED" /domain on specific permissions groups.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Malware used by Ke3chang can run commands on the command-line interface.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang has dumped credentials, including by using Mimikatz.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: The Ke3chang group has been known to compress data before exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang is known to use RAR with passwords to encrypt data prior to exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Information Repositories
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang used a SharePoint enumeration and data dumping tool known as spwebmember.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang gathered information and files from local directories for exfiltration.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang used a .NET tool to dump data from Microsoft Exchange mailboxes.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang transferred compressed and encrypted RAR files containing exfiltration through the established backdoor command and control channel during operations.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: External Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang regained access after eviction via the corporate VPN solution with a stolen VPN certificate, which they had extracted from a compromised host.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang uses command-line interaction to search files and directories.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang has used keyloggers.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang backdoor RoyalDNS established persistence through adding a service called Nwsapagent.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Pass the Ticket
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang has used Mimikatz to generate Kerberos golden tickets.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang performs discovery of permission groups net group /domain.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang performs process discovery using tasklist commands.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Several Ke3chang backdoors achieved persistence by adding a Run key.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang has used network scanning and enumeration tools, including Ping.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang has used batch scripts in its malware to install persistence mechanisms.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Service Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang has used a tool known as RemoteExec (similar to PsExec) to remotely execute batch scripts and binaries.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang malware RoyalCli and BS2005 have communicated over HTTP with the C2 server through Internet Explorer (IE) by using the COM interface IWebBrowser2. Additionally, Ke3chang malware RoyalDNS has used DNS for C2.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang performs operating system information discovery using systeminfo.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang performs local network configuration discovery using ipconfig.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang performs local network connection discovery using netstat.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang performs service discovery using net start commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Ke3chang actors have been known to copy files to the network shares of other computers to move laterally.[1][2]

Lazarus Group.Name: Lazarus Group
Lazarus Group.Description: Lazarus Group is a threat group that has been attributed to the North Korean government. [1] The group has been active since at least 2009 and was reportedly responsible for the November 2014 destructive wiper attack against Sony Pictures Entertainment as part of a campaign named Operation Blockbuster by Novetta. Malware used by Lazarus Group correlates to other reported campaigns, including Operation Flame, Operation 1Mission, Operation Troy, DarkSeoul, and Ten Days of Rain. [2] In late 2017, Lazarus Group used KillDisk, a disk-wiping tool, in an attack against an online casino based in Central America. [3]
Lazarus Group.Aliases: Lazarus Group, HIDDEN COBRA, Guardians of Peace, ZINC, NICKEL ACADEMY

Techniques Used.Name: Access Token Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group keylogger KiloAlfa obtains user tokens from interactive sessions to execute itself with API call CreateProcessAsUserA under that user's context.[2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Manipulation
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware WhiskeyDelta-Two contains a function that attempts to rename the administrator’s account.[2][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Application Window Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server the title of the window for each running process. The KilaAlfa keylogger also reports the title of the window in the foreground.[2][6][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Bootkit
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware WhiskeyAlfa-Three modifies sector 0 of the Master Boot Record (MBR) to ensure that the malware will persist even if a victim machine shuts down.[2][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Brute Force
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware attempts to connect to Windows shares for lateral movement by using a generated list of usernames, which center around permutations of the username Administrator, and weak passwords.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware uses cmd.exe to execute commands on victims.[2][5][8][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Some Lazarus Group malware uses a list of ordered port numbers to choose a port for C2 traffic, which includes commonly used ports such as 443, 53, 80, 25, and 8080.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Compiled HTML File
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group has used CHM files to move concealed payloads as part of.[10]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group uses multiple proxies to obfuscate network traffic from victims.[11]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group leveraged Mimikatz to extract Windows Credentials of currently logged-in users and steals passwords stored in browsers.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Several Lazarus Group malware families encrypt C2 traffic using custom code that uses XOR with an ADD operation and XOR with a SUB operation. Another Lazarus Group malware sample XORs C2 traffic. Lazarus Group malware also uses a unique form of communication encryption known as FakeTLS that mimics TLS but uses a different encryption method, evading SSL man-in-the-middle decryption attacks.[2][5][8][12]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is compressed with Zlib, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server. Lazarus Group malware RomeoDelta archives specified directories in .zip format, encrypts the .zip file, and uploads it to its C2 server.[2][6][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: A Lazarus Group malware sample encodes data with base64.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is compressed with Zlib, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server. Lazarus Group malware RomeoDelta archives specified directories in .zip format, encrypts the .zip file, and uploads it to its C2 server. A Lazarus Group malware sample encrypts data using a simple byte based XOR operation prior to exfiltration.[2][6][7][8]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is uploaded to one of its 10 C2 servers. Lazarus Group malware RomeoDelta copies specified directories from the victim's machine, then archives and encrypts the directories before uploading to its C2 server.[2][6][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is saved in the %TEMP% directory, then compressed, encrypted, and uploaded to a C2 server.[2][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Various Lazarus Group malware modifies the Windows firewall to allow incoming connections or disable it entirely using netsh. Lazarus Group malware TangoDelta attempts to terminate various processes associated with McAfee. Additionally, Lazarus Group malware SHARPKNOT disables the Microsoft Windows System Event Notification and Alerter services.[2][6][4][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group delivered RATANKBA to victims via a compromised legitimate website.[13]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware SierraBravo-Two generates an email message via SMTP containing information about newly infected victims.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia saves information gathered about the victim to a file that is uploaded to one of its 10 C2 servers. Another Lazarus Group malware sample also performs exfiltration over the C2 channel.[2][6][8]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group has exploited Adobe Flash vulnerability CVE-2018-4878 for execution.[14]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware SierraAlfa sends data to one of the hard-coded C2 servers chosen at random, and if the transmission fails, chooses a new C2 server to attempt the transmission again.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Several Lazarus Group malware samples use a common function to identify target files by their extension. Lazarus Group malware families can also enumerate files and directories, including a Destover-like variant that lists files and gathers information for all drives.[2][12]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware deletes files in various ways, including "suicide scripts" to delete malware binaries from the victim. Lazarus Group also uses secure file deletion to delete files from the victim. Additionally, Lazarus Group malware SHARPKNOT overwrites and deletes the Master Boot Record (MBR) on the victim's machine.[2][12][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Hidden Files and Directories
Techniques Used.Use: A Lazarus Group VBA Macro sets its file attributes to System and Hidden.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware KiloAlfa contains keylogging functionality.[2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Multiband Communication
Techniques Used.Use: Some Lazarus Group malware uses multiple channels for C2, such as RomeoWhiskey-Two, which consists of a RAT channel that parses data in datagram form and a Proxy channel that forms virtual point-to-point sessions.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: Several Lazarus Group malware families install themselves as new services on victims.[2][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware uses multiple types of encryption and encoding in its malware files, including AES, Caracachs, RC4, basic XOR with constant 0xA7, and other techniques.[2][6][7][8]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Several Lazarus Group malware families gather a list of running processes on a victim system and send it to their C2 server. A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group also gathers process times.[2][6][8][12]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: A Lazarus Group malware sample performs reflective DLL injection.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia checks Registry keys within HKCU and HKLM to determine if certain applications are present, including SecureCRT, Terminal Services, RealVNC, TightVNC, UltraVNC, Radmin, mRemote, TeamViewer, FileZilla, pcAnyware, and Remote Desktop. Another Lazarus Group malware sample checks for the presence of the following Registry key:HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Bitcoin\Bitcoin-Qt.[2][6][8]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware attempts to maintain persistence by saving itself in the Start menu folder or by adding a Registry Run key.[2][7][8]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware SierraCharlie uses RDP for propagation.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Several Lazarus Group malware families are capable of downloading and executing binaries from its C2 server.[2][5][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group uses a batch file mechanism to delete its binaries from the system.[12]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: A Lazarus Group malware sample adds persistence on the system by creating a shortcut in the user’s Startup folder.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Word documents.[14]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: A Lazarus Group malware sample conducts C2 over HTTP.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware uses Caracachs encryption to encrypt C2 payloads.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Several Lazarus Group malware families collect information on the type and version of the victim OS, as well as the victim computer name and CPU information. A Destover-like variant used by Lazarus Group also collects disk space information and sends it to its C2 server.[2][5][6][8][12]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server information about the first network interface card’s configuration, including IP address, gateways, subnet mask, DHCP information, and whether WINS is available.[2][6]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Various Lazarus Group malware enumerates logged-on users.[2][5][6][7][8]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A Destover-like implant used by Lazarus Group can obtain the current system time and send it to the C2 server.[12]

Techniques Used.Name: Timestomp
Techniques Used.Use: Several Lazarus Group malware families use timestomping, including modifying the last write timestamp of a specified Registry key to a random date, as well as copying the timestamp for legitimate .exe files (such as calc.exe or mspaint.exe) to its dropped files.[2][5][6][12]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Some Lazarus Group malware uses a list of ordered port numbers to choose a port for C2 traffic, which includes uncommonly used ports such as 995, 1816, 465, 1521, 3306, and many others.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group has attempted to get users to launch a malicious Microsoft Word attachment delivered via a spearphishing email.[14]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Lazarus Group malware SierraAlfa accesses the ADMIN$ share via SMB to conduct lateral movement.[2][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation

Leafminer.Name: Leafminer
Leafminer.Description: Leafminer is an Iranian threat group that has targeted government organizations and business entities in the Middle East since at least early 2017. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Brute Force
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer used a tool called BruteForcer to perform a brute force attack.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Create Account
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer used a tool called Imecab to set up a persistent remote access account on the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer leveraged the tool LaZagne for retrieving login and password information.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer has infected victims using watering holes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer used a tool called MailSniper to search through the Exchange server mailboxes for keywords.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer used a tool called MailSniper to search for files on the desktop and another utility called Sobolsoft to extract attachments from EML files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer scanned network services to search for vulnerabilities in the victim system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer obfuscated scripts that were used on victim machines.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Redundant Access
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer used a tool called Imecab to set up a persistent remote access account on the victim machine.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer used Microsoft’s Sysinternals tools to gather detailed information about remote systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Leafminer infected victims using JavaScript code.[1]

Leviathan.Name: Leviathan
Leviathan.Description: Leviathan is a cyber espionage group that has been active since at least 2013. The group generally targets defense and government organizations, but has also targeted a range of industries including engineering firms, shipping and transportation, manufacturing, defense, government offices, and research universities in the United States, Western Europe, and along the South China Sea. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has inserted garbage characters into code, presumably to avoid anti-virus detection.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: BITS Jobs
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used bitsadmin.exe to download additional tools.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used stolen code signing certificates used to sign malware.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan uses a backdoor known as BADFLICK that is is capable of generating a reverse shell.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used C:\Windows\Debug and C:\Perflogs as staging directories.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used a DLL known as SeDll to decrypt and execute other JavaScript backdoors.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has exploited multiple Microsoft Office and .NET vulnerabilities for execution, including CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-8759, and CVE-2017-11882.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has obfuscated code using base64 and gzip compression.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used PowerShell for execution.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used JavaScript to create a shortcut file in the Startup folder that points to its main backdoor.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Regsvr32
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used regsvr32 for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has downloaded additional scripts and files from adversary-controlled servers. Leviathan has also used an uploader known as LUNCHMONEY that can exfiltrate files to Dropbox.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used multiple types of scripting for execution, including JavaScript, JavaScript Scriptlets in XML, and VBScript.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Shortcut Modification
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used JavaScript to create a shortcut file in the Startup folder that points to its main backdoor.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments, including .rtf, .doc, and .xls files.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has sent spearphishing emails with links, often using a fraudulent lookalike domain and stolen branding.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has sent spearphishing emails links and attachments attempting to get a user to click.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used valid, compromised email accounts for defense evasion, including to send malicious emails to other victim organizations.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has received C2 instructions from user profiles created on legitimate websites such as Github and TechNet.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used WMI for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
Techniques Used.Use: Leviathan has used WMI for persistence.[2]

Magic Hound.Name: Magic Hound
Magic Hound.Description: Magic Hound is an Iranian-sponsored threat group operating primarily in the Middle East that dates back as early as 2014. The group behind the campaign has primarily targeted organizations in the energy, government, and technology sectors that are either based or have business interests in Saudi Arabia. [1] [2]
Magic Hound.Aliases: Magic Hound, Rocket Kitten, Operation Saffron Rose, Ajax Security Team, Operation Woolen-Goldfish, Newscaster, Cobalt Gypsy, APT35

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound has used the command-line interface.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware has communicated with C2 servers over port 6667 (for IRC) and port 8080.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound stole domain credentials from Microsoft Active Directory Domain Controller and leveraged Mimikatz.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound has used RAR to stage and compress local folders.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Email Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound has collected .PST archives.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware can list a victim's logical drives and the type, as well the total/free space of the fixed devices. Other malware can list a directory's contents.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound has deleted and overwrote files to cover tracks.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware is capable of keylogging.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware has used base64-encoded commands and files, and has also encrypted embedded strings with AES.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound has used PowerShell for execution and privilege escalation.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware can list running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware has used Registry Run keys to establish persistence.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound has downloaded additional code and files from servers onto victims.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware can take a screenshot and upload the file to its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware has used .vbs scripts for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound sent malicious attachments to victims over email, including an Excel spreadsheet containing macros to download Pupy.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound sent shortened URL links over email to victims. The URLs linked to Word documents with malicious macros that execute PowerShells scripts to download Pupy.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing via Service
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound used various social media channels to spearphish victims.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware has used HTTP and IRC for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware has used a PowerShell command to check the victim system architecture to determine if it is an x64 machine. Other malware has obtained the OS version, UUID, and computer/host name to send to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware gathers the victim's local IP address, MAC address, and external IP address.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware has obtained the victim username and sent it to the C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Uncommonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware has communicated with its C2 server over ports 4443 and 3543.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound has attempted to get users to execute malware via social media and spearphishing emails.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: Magic Hound malware can use a SOAP Web service to communicate with its C2 server.[1]

menuPass.Name: menuPass
menuPass.Description: menuPass is a threat group that appears to originate from China and has been active since approximately 2009. The group has targeted healthcare, defense, aerospace, and government sectors, and has targeted Japanese victims since at least 2014. In 2016 and 2017, the group targeted managed IT service providers, manufacturing and mining companies, and a university. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5]
menuPass.Aliases: menuPass, Stone Panda, APT10, Red Apollo, CVNX, HOGFISH

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used the Microsoft administration tool csvde.exe to export Active Directory data.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass executes commands using a command-line interface and reverse shell. The group has used a modified version of pentesting script wmiexec.vbs to execute commands.[4][6][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used a global service provider's IP as a proxy for C2 traffic from a victim.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used a modified version of pentesting tools wmiexec.vbs and secretsdump.py to dump credentials.[6][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has compressed files before exfiltration using TAR and RAR.[4][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Network Shared Drive
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has collected data from remote systems by mounting network shares with net use and using Robocopy to transfer data.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass stages data prior to exfiltration in multi-part archives, often saved in the Recycle Bin.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used certutil in a macro to decode base64-encoded content contained in a dropper document attached to an email. The group has used certutil -decode to decode files on the victim’s machine when dropping UPPERCUT.[8][9]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used DLL search order hijacking.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used DLL side-loading to launch versions of Mimikatz and PwDump6 as well as UPPERCUT.[6][9]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: A menuPass macro deletes files after it has decoded and decompressed them.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used tcping.exe, similar to Ping, to probe port status on systems of interest.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has encoded strings in its malware with base64 as well as with a simple, single-byte XOR obfuscation using key 0x40.[8][9]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass uses PowerSploit to inject shellcode into PowerShell.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used process hollowing in iexplore.exe to load the RedLeaves implant.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used RDP connections to move across the victim network.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has installed updates and new malware on victims.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used Putty Secure Copy Client (PSCP) to transfer data.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass uses scripts to enumerate IP ranges on the victim network. menuPass has also issued the command net view /domain to a PlugX implant to gather information about remote systems on the network.[6][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used a script (atexec.py) to execute a command on a target machine via Task Scheduler.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used malicious macros embedded inside Office documents to execute files.[8][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has sent malicious Office documents via email as part of spearphishing campaigns as well as executables disguised as documents.[6][5][9]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used several tools to scan for open NetBIOS nameservers and enumerate NetBIOS sessions.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used net use to conduct connectivity checks to machines.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Trusted Relationship
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used legitimate access granted to Managed Service Providers in order to access victims of interest.[6][5]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has attempted to get victims to open malicious files sent via email as part of spearphishing campaigns.[6][5][8]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass has used valid accounts shared between Managed Service Providers and clients to move between the two environments.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: menuPass uses a modified version of pentesting script wmiexec.vbs, which logs into a remote machine using WMI.[6][7]

MuddyWater.Name: MuddyWater
MuddyWater.Description: MuddyWater is an Iranian threat group that has primarily targeted Middle Eastern nations. Activity from this group was previously linked to FIN7, but is believed to be a distinct group motivated by espionage. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: CMSTP
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater has used CMSTP.exe and a malicious INF to execute its POWERSTATS payload.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater has performed credential dumping with Mimikatz and Lazagne.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater decoded base64-encoded PowerShell commands using a VBS file.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater has used filenames and Registry key names associated with Windows Defender.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Mshta
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater has used Mshta.exe to execute its POWERSTATS payload.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater has used Daniel Bohannon’s Invoke-Obfuscation framework. The group also used files with base64 encoded PowerShell commands.[1][4][2]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater has used PowerShell for execution.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater has added Registry Run keys to establish persistence.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater has used VBScript and JavaScript files to execute its POWERSTATS payload.[2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: MuddyWater has compromised third parties and used compromised accounts to send spearphishing emails with targeted attachments to recipients.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution

Naikon.Name: Naikon
Naikon.Description: Naikon is a threat group that has focused on targets around the South China Sea. [1] The group has been attributed to the Chinese People’s Liberation Army’s (PLA) Chengdu Military Region Second Technical Reconnaissance Bureau (Military Unit Cover Designator 78020). [2] While Naikon shares some characteristics with APT30, the two groups do not appear to be exact matches. [3]

Techniques Used.Use: Naikon uses commands such as netsh advfirewall firewall to discover local firewall settings.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Naikon uses commands such as netsh interface show to discover network interface settings.[1]

NEODYMIUM.Name: NEODYMIUM
NEODYMIUM.Description: NEODYMIUM is an activity group that conducted a campaign in May 2016 and has heavily targeted Turkish victims. The group has demonstrated similarity to another activity group called PROMETHIUM due to overlapping victim and campaign characteristics. [1] [2] NEODYMIUM is reportedly associated closely with BlackOasis operations, but evidence that the group names are aliases has not been identified. [3]

Software.Name: Wingbird
Software.Techniques: DLL Side-Loading, Exploitation for Privilege Escalation, File Deletion, LSASS Driver, New Service, Process Injection, Security Software Discovery, Service Execution, System Information Discovery

Night Dragon.Name: Night Dragon
Night Dragon.Description: Night Dragon is a campaign name for activity involving threat group that has conducted activity originating primarily in China. [1] The activity from this group is also known as Musical Chairs. [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Acquire and/or use 3rd party infrastructure services
Techniques Used.Use: Night Dragon used servers in China, the U.S., and the Netherlands in an attempt to hide their operations.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Acquire and/or use 3rd party software services
Techniques Used.Use: Night Dragon used third party hosting services in the U.S. in an attempt to hide their operations.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote access tool development
Techniques Used.Use: Night Dragon used privately developed and customized remote access tools.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: Night Dragon is known to use software packing in its tools.[1]

OilRig.Name: OilRig
OilRig.Description: OilRig is a threat group with suspected Iranian origins that has targeted Middle Eastern and international victims since at least 2014. The group has targeted a variety of industries, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications, and has largely focused its operations within the Middle East. It appears the group carries out supply chain attacks, leveraging the trust relationship between organizations to attack their primary targets. FireEye assesses that the group works on behalf of the Iranian government based on infrastructure details that contain references to Iran, use of Iranian infrastructure, and targeting that aligns with nation-state interests. [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] This group was previously tracked under two distinct groups, APT34 and OilRig, but was combined due to additional reporting giving higher confidence about the overlap of the activity.

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has run net user, net user /domain, net group “domain admins” /domain, and net group “Exchange Trusted Subsystem” /domain to get account listings on a victim.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used automated collection.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Brute Force
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used brute force techniques to obtain credentials.[7]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used the command-line interface for execution.[6][8][5][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Compiled HTML File
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used a CHM payload to load and execute another malicious file once delivered to a victim.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as Mimikatz and Lazagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[5][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used custom DNS Tunneling protocols for C2.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: A OilRig macro has run a PowerShell command to decode file contents. OilRig has also used certutil to decode base64-encoded files on victims.[6][9][8]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has exfiltrated data over FTP separately from its primary C2 channel over DNS.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: External Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig uses remote services such as VPN, Citrix, or OWA to persist in an environment.[7]

Techniques Used.Name: Fallback Channels
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig malware ISMAgent falls back to its DNS tunneling mechanism if it is unable to reach the C2 server over HTTP.[10]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has deleted files associated with their payload after execution.[6][8]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has tested malware samples to determine AV detection and subsequently modified the samples to ensure AV evasion.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used a keylogging tool called KEYPUNCH.[7]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used the publicly available tool SoftPerfect Network Scanner as well as a custom tool called GOLDIRONY to conduct network scanning.[7]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has encrypted and encoded data in its malware, including by using base64.[6][11][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Password Policy Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used net.exe in a script with net accounts /domain to find the password policy of a domain.[12]

Techniques Used.Name: Permission Groups Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used net group /domain, net localgroup administrators, net group “domain admins” /domain, and net group “Exchange Trusted Subsystem” /domain to find group permission settings on a victim.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used PowerShell scripts for execution, including use of a macro to run a PowerShell command to decode file contents.[6][9]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has run tasklist on a victim's machine.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used reg query “HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default” on a victim to query the Registry.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Redundant Access
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used RGDoor via Web shell to establish redundant access. The group has also used harvested credentials to gain access to Internet-accessible resources such as Outlook Web Access, which could be used for redundant access.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used Remote Desktop Protocol for lateral movement. The group has also used tunneling tools to tunnel RDP into the environment.[5][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig can download remote files onto victims.[6]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used Putty to access compromised systems.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has created scheduled tasks that run a VBScript to execute a payload on victim machines.[8][11]

Techniques Used.Name: Screen Capture
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has a tool called CANDYKING to capture a screenshot of user's desktop.[7]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used various types of scripting for execution, including .bat and .vbs scripts. The group has also used macros to deliver malware such as QUADAGENT and OopsIE.[6][10][8][11]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious attachments to potential victims using compromised and/or spoofed email accounts.[8][11]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious links to potential victims.[8]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used HTTP and DNS for C2. The group has also used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.[5][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.[7]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has run hostname and systeminfo on a victim.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has run ipconfig /all on a victim.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used netstat -an on a victim to get a listing of network connections.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has run whoami on a victim.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used sc query on a victim to gather information about services.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has delivered malicious links and macro-enabled documents that required targets to click the "enable content" button to execute the payload on the system.[8][11]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used compromised credentials to access other systems on a victim network.[5][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Shell
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used Web shells, often to maintain access to a victim network.[5][7]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: OilRig has used WMI for execution.[7]

Patchwork.Name: Patchwork
Patchwork.Description: Patchwork is a cyberespionage group that was first observed in December 2015. While the group has not been definitively attributed, circumstantial evidence suggests the group may be a pro-Indian or Indian entity. Patchwork has been seen targeting industries related to diplomatic and government agencies. Much of the code used by this group was copied and pasted from online forums. Patchwork was also seen operating spearphishing campaigns targeting U.S. think tank groups in March and April of 2018. [1] [2] [3] [4]
Patchwork.Aliases: Patchwork, Dropping Elephant, Chinastrats, MONSOON, Operation Hangover

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork developed a file stealer to search C:\ and collect files with certain extensions. Patchwork also executed a script to enumerate all drives, store them as a list, and upload generated files to the C2 server.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Binary Padding
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork apparently altered NDiskMonitor samples by adding four bytes of random letters in a likely attempt to change the file hashes.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork bypassed User Access Control (UAC).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork ran a reverse shell with Meterpreter.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork dumped the login data database from \AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\Default\Login Data.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encoding
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork used Base64 to encode C2 traffic.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork encrypted the collected files' path with AES and then encoded them with base64.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork collected and exfiltrated files from the infected system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork copied all targeted files to a directory called index that was eventually uploaded to the C&C server.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: A Patchwork .dll that contains BADNEWS is loaded and executed using DLL side-loading.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork has used watering holes to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[2][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Dynamic Data Exchange
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork leveraged the DDE protocol to deliver their malware.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork uses malicious documents to deliver remote execution exploits as part of. The group has previously exploited CVE-2017-8570, CVE-2012-1856, CVE-2014-4114, CVE-2017-0199, and CVE-2015-1641.[1][5][2][6][3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: A Patchwork payload has searched all fixed drives on the victim for files matching a specified list of extensions.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork removed certain files and replaced them so they could not be retrieved.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork apparently altered NDiskMonitor samples by adding four bytes of random letters in a likely attempt to change the file hashes.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork installed its payload in the startup programs folder as "Baidu Software Update." The group also adds its second stage payload to the startup programs as “Net Monitor."[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: A Patchwork payload deletes Resiliency Registry keys created by Microsoft Office applications in an apparent effort to trick users into thinking there were no issues during application runs.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork has obfuscated a script with Crypto Obfuscator.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork used PowerSploit to download payloads, run a reverse shell, and execute malware on the victim's machine.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Hollowing
Techniques Used.Use: A Patchwork payload uses process hollowing to hide the UAC bypass vulnerability exploitation inside svchost.exe.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork has added the path of its second-stage malware to the startup folder to achieve persistence. One of its file stealers has also persisted by adding a Registry Run key.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Desktop Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork attempted to use RDP to move laterally.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork payloads download additional files from the C2 server.[5][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: A Patchwork file stealer can run a TaskScheduler DLL to add persistence.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork used Visual Basic Scripts (VBS), JavaScript code, batch files, and .SCT files on victim machines.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Security Software Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork scanned the “Program Files” directories for a directory with the string “Total Security” (the installation path of the “360 Total Security” antivirus tool).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Software Packing
Techniques Used.Use: A Patchwork payload was packed with UPX.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork has used spearphishing with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[1][5][3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork has used spearphishing with links to deliver files with exploits to initial victims. The group has used embedded image tags (known as web bugs) with unique, per-recipient tracking links in their emails for the purpose of identifying which recipients opened messages.[2][3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork collected the victim computer name, OS version, and architecture type and sent the information to its C2 server. Patchwork also enumerated all available drives on the victim's machine.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork collected the victim username and whether it was running as admin, then sent the information to its C2 server.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork embedded a malicious macro in a Word document and lured the victim to click on an icon to execute the malware.[3][4]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: Patchwork hides base64-encoded and encrypted C2 server locations in comments on legitimate websites.[5]
