PLATINUM.Name: PLATINUM
PLATINUM.Description: PLATINUM is an activity group that has targeted victims since at least 2009. The group has focused on targets associated with governments and related organizations in South and Southeast Asia. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has used keyloggers that are also capable of dumping credentials.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Custom Command and Control Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has used the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel for command and control.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has sometimes used drive-by attacks against vulnerable browser plugins.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has leveraged a zero-day vulnerability to escalate privileges.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Hooking
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM is capable of using Windows hook interfaces for information gathering such as credential access.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has used several different keyloggers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has used various methods of process injection including hot patching.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has transferred files using the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has sent spearphishing emails with attachments to victims as its primary initial access vector.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Non-Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has used the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel for command and control.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: PLATINUM has attempted to get users to open malicious files by sending spearphishing emails with attachments to victims.[1]

Poseidon Group.Name: Poseidon Group
Poseidon Group.Description: Poseidon Group is a Portuguese-speaking threat group that has been active since at least 2005. The group has a history of using information exfiltrated from victims to blackmail victim companies into contracting the Poseidon Group as a security firm. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Poseidon Group searches for administrator accounts on both the local victim machine and the network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Poseidon Group conducts credential dumping on victims, with a focus on obtaining credentials belonging to domain and database servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Poseidon Group tools attempt to spoof anti-virus processes as a means of self-defense.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: The Poseidon Group's Information Gathering Tool (IGT) includes PowerShell components.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: After compromising a victim, Poseidon Group lists all running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Poseidon Group obtains and saves information about victim network interfaces and addresses.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: After compromising a victim, Poseidon Group discovers all running services.[1]

PROMETHIUM.Name: PROMETHIUM
PROMETHIUM.Description: PROMETHIUM is an activity group that has been active since at least 2012. The group conducted a campaign in May 2016 and has heavily targeted Turkish victims. PROMETHIUM has demonstrated similarity to another activity group called NEODYMIUM due to overlapping victim and campaign characteristics. [1] [2]

Software.Name: Truvasys
Software.Techniques: Masquerading, Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder

Putter Panda.Name: Putter Panda
Putter Panda.Description: Putter Panda is a Chinese threat group that has been attributed to Unit 61486 of the 12th Bureau of the PLA’s 3rd General Staff Department (GSD). [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Malware used by Putter Panda attempts to terminate processes corresponding to two components of Sophos Anti-Virus (SAVAdminService.exe and SavService.exe).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: Droppers used by Putter Panda use RC4 or a 16-byte XOR key consisting of the bytes 0xA0 – 0xAF to obfuscate payloads.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: An executable dropped onto victims by Putter Panda aims to inject the specified DLL into a process that would normally be accessing the network, including Outlook Express (msinm.exe), Outlook (outlook.exe), Internet Explorer (iexplore.exe), and Firefox (firefox.exe).[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: A dropper used by Putter Panda installs itself into the ASEP Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run with a value named McUpdate.[1]

Rancor.Name: Rancor
Rancor.Description: Rancor is a threat group that has led targeted campaigns against the South East Asia region. Rancor uses politically-motivated lures to entice victims to open malicious documents. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Rancor has used cmd.exe to execute commmands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Rancor has downloaded additional malware, including by using certutil.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Rancor launched a scheduled task to gain persistence using the schtasks /create /sc command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Rancor has used shell and VBS scripts as well as embedded macros for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: Rancor has attached a malicious document to an email to gain initial access.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Rancor has used HTTP for C2.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Rancor attempted to get users to click on an embedded macro within a Microsoft Office Excel document to launch their malware.[1]

RTM.Name: RTM
RTM.Description: RTM is a cybercriminal group that has been active since at least 2015 and is primarily interested in users of remote banking systems in Russia and neighboring countries. The group uses a Trojan by the same name (RTM). [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: RTM has used an RSS feed on Livejournal to update a list of encrypted C2 server names.[1]

Sandworm Team.Name: Sandworm Team
Sandworm Team.Description:
Sandworm Team is a Russian cyber espionage group that has operated since approximately 2009. The group likely consists of Russian pro-hacktivists. Sandworm Team targets mainly Ukrainian entities associated with energy, industrial control systems, SCADA, government, and media. Sandworm Team has been linked to the Ukrainian energy sector attack in late 2015.
 [1] [2]

Scarlet Mimic.Name: Scarlet Mimic
Scarlet Mimic.Description: Scarlet Mimic is a threat group that has targeted minority rights activists. This group has not been directly linked to a government source, but the group's motivations appear to overlap with those of the Chinese government. While there is some overlap between IP addresses used by Scarlet Mimic and Putter Panda, it has not been concluded that the groups are the same. [1]

Sowbug.Name: Sowbug
Sowbug.Description: Sowbug is a threat group that has conducted targeted attacks against organizations in South America and Southeast Asia, particularly government entities, since at least 2015. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Sowbug has used command line during its intrusions.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Sowbug has used credential dumping tools.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Sowbug extracted documents and bundled them into a RAR archive.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Network Shared Drive
Techniques Used.Use: Sowbug extracted Word documents from a file server on a victim network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sowbug identified and extracted all Word documents on a server by using a command containing * .doc and *.docx. The actors also searched for documents based on a specific date range and attempted to identify all installed software on a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Sowbug has used keylogging tools.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Masquerading
Techniques Used.Use: Sowbug named its tools to masquerade as Windows or Adobe Reader software, such as by using the file name adobecms.exe and the directory CSIDL_APPDATA\microsoft\security.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sowbug listed remote shared drives that were accessible from a victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Sowbug obtained OS version and hardware configuration from a victim.[1]

Stealth Falcon.Name: Stealth Falcon
Stealth Falcon.Description: Stealth Falcon is a threat group that has conducted targeted spyware attacks against Emirati journalists, activists, and dissidents since at least 2012. Circumstantial evidence suggests there could be a link between this group and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) government, but that has not been confirmed. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware gathers passwords from multiple sources, including Windows Credential Vault, Internet Explorer, Firefox, Chrome, and Outlook.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware gathers data from the local victim system.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
Techniques Used.Use: After data is collected by Stealth Falcon malware, it is exfiltrated over the existing C2 channel.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware uses PowerShell commands to perform various functions, including gathering system information via WMI and executing commands from its C2 server.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware gathers a list of running processes.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware attempts to determine the installed version of .NET by querying the Registry.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware creates a scheduled task entitled “IE Web Cache” to execute a malicious file hourly.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware uses PowerShell and WMI to script data collection and command execution on the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware communicates with its C2 server via HTTPS.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a hard-coded key.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware gathers system information via WMI, including the system directory, build number, serial number, version, manufacturer, model, and total physical memory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware gathers the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) table from the victim.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware gathers the registered user and primary owner name via WMI.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: Stealth Falcon malware gathers system information via Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).[1]

Strider.Name: Strider
Strider.Description: Strider is a threat group that has been active since at least 2011 and has targeted victims in Russia, China, Sweden, Belgium, Iran, and Rwanda. [1] [2]

Techniques Used.Name: Connection Proxy
Techniques Used.Use: Strider has used local servers with both local network and Internet access to act as internal proxy nodes to exfiltrate data from other parts of the network without direct Internet access.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Strider has registered its persistence module on domain controllers as a Windows LSA (Local System Authority) password filter to dump credentials any time a domain, local user, or administrator logs in or changes a password.[3]

Suckfly.Name: Suckfly
Suckfly.Description: Suckfly is a China-based threat group that has been active since at least 2014. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Suckfly has used stolen certificates to sign its malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Several tools used by Suckfly have been command-line driven.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Suckfly used a signed credential-dumping tool to obtain victim account credentials.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: Suckfly the victim's internal network for hosts with ports 8080, 5900, and 40 open.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Suckfly used legitimate account credentials that they dumped to navigate the internal victim network as though they were the legitimate account owner.[2]

TA459.Name: TA459
TA459.Description: TA459 is a threat group believed to operate out of China that has targeted countries including Russia, Belarus, Mongolia, and others. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Client Execution
Techniques Used.Use: TA459 has exploited Microsoft Word vulnerability CVE-2017-0199 for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: TA459 has used PowerShell for execution of a payload.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Scripting
Techniques Used.Use: TA459 has a VBScript for execution.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Techniques Used.Use: TA459 has targeted victims using spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: TA459 has attempted to get victims to open malicious Microsoft Word attachment sent via spearphishing.[1]

Taidoor.Name: Taidoor
Taidoor.Description: Taidoor is a threat group that has operated since at least 2009 and has primarily targeted the Taiwanese government. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Cryptographic Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Taidoor uses RC4 to encrypt the message body of HTTP content.[1]

Threat Group-1314.Name: Threat Group-1314
Threat Group-1314.Description: Threat Group-1314 is an unattributed threat group that has used compromised credentials to log into a victim's remote access infrastructure. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-1314 actors spawned shells on remote systems on a victim network to execute commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Third-party Software
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-1314 actors used a victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, for lateral movement.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-1314 actors used compromised credentials for the victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, to move laterally.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-1314 actors mapped network drives using net use.[1]

Software.Techniques: Service Execution, Windows Admin Shares

Threat Group-3390.Name: Threat Group-3390
Threat Group-3390.Description: Threat Group-3390 is a Chinese threat group that has extensively used strategic Web compromises to target victims. [1] The group has been active since at least 2010 and has targeted organizations in the aerospace, government, defense, technology, energy, and manufacturing sectors. [2] [3]
Threat Group-3390.Aliases: Threat Group-3390, TG-3390, Emissary Panda, BRONZE UNION, APT27, Iron Tiger, LuckyMouse

Techniques Used.Name: Account Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used net user to conduct internal discovery of systems.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Automated Collection
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Bypass User Account Control
Techniques Used.Use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can use a public UAC bypass method to elevate privileges.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Command-Line Interface
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used command-line interfaces for execution.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Commonly Used Port
Techniques Used.Use: C2 traffic for most Threat Group-3390 tools occurs over Port Numbers 53, 80, and 443.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Credential Dumping
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 actors have used gsecdump and a modified version of Mimikatz called Wrapikatz to dump credentials. They have also dumped credentials from domain controllers.[1][2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Compressed
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used RAR to compress, encrypt, and password-protect files prior to exfiltration.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Encrypted
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used RAR to compress, encrypt, and password-protect files prior to exfiltration.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data from Local System
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Staged
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has staged encrypted archives for exfiltration on Internet-facing servers that had previously been compromised with China Chopper.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Data Transfer Size Limits
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: During execution, Threat Group-3390 malware deobfuscates and decompresses code that was encoded with Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: Disabling Security Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used appcmd.exe to disable logging on a victim server.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Search Order Hijacking
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has performed DLL search order hijacking to execute their payload.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: DLL Side-Loading
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 actors have used DLL side-loading. Actors have used legitimate Kaspersky anti-virus variants in which the DLL acts as a stub loader that loads and executes the shell code.[1][2][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has has extensively used strategic Web compromises to target victims.[1][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used CVE-2014-6324 to escalate privileges.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: External Remote Services
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 actors look for and use VPN profiles during an operation to access the network using external VPN services.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File Deletion
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has deleted existing logs and exfiltrated file archives from a victim.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Input Capture
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 actors installed a credential logger on Microsoft Exchange servers. Threat Group-3390 also leveraged the reconnaissance framework, ScanBox, to capture keystrokes.[1][5][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Modify Registry
Techniques Used.Use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can create a new Registry key under HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Service Scanning
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 actors use the Hunter tool to conduct network service discovery for vulnerable systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Network Share Connection Removal
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has detached network shares after exfiltrating files, likely to evade detection.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: New Service
Techniques Used.Use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can create a new service, naming it after the config information, to gain persistence.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information
Techniques Used.Use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can encrypt payloads using XOR. Threat Group-3390 malware is also obfuscated using Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.[4][3]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used PowerShell for execution.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can spawn svchost.exe and inject the payload into that process.[4][3]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can read and decrypt stored Registry values.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Redundant Access
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has deployed backup web shells and obtained OWA account credentials during intrusions that it subsequently used to attempt to regain access when evicted from a victim network.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can add the binary’s path to the Registry key Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to add persistence.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: After re-establishing access to a victim network, Threat Group-3390 actors download tools including gsecdump and WCE that are staged temporarily on websites that were previously compromised but never used.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used the net view command.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Scheduled Task
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 actors use at to schedule tasks to run self-extracting RAR archives, which install HTTPBrowser or PlugX on other victims on a network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 malware has used HTTP for C2.[3]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 actors use nbtscan to discover vulnerable systems.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used net use to conduct internal discovery of systems. The group has also used quser.exe to identify existing RDP sessions on a victim.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: Valid Accounts
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 actors obtain legitimate credentials using a variety of methods and use them to further lateral movement on victim networks.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Techniques Used.Use: A Threat Group-3390 tool can use WMI to execute a binary.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Remote Management
Techniques Used.Use: Threat Group-3390 has used WinRM to enable remote execution.[2]

Thrip.Name: Thrip
Thrip.Description: Thrip is an espionage group that has targeted satellite communications, telecoms, and defense contractor companies in the U.S. and Southeast Asia. The group uses custom malware as well as "living off the land" techniques. [1]

Techniques Used.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Thrip has used WinSCP to exfiltrate data from a targeted organization over FTP.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Thrip leveraged PowerShell to run commands to download payloads, traverse the compromised networks, and carry out reconnaissance.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote Access Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Thrip used a cloud-based remote access software called LogMeIn for their attacks.[1]

Turla.Name: Turla
Turla.Description: Turla is a Russian-based threat group that has infected victims in over 45 countries, spanning a range of industries including government, embassies, military, education, research and pharmaceutical companies since 2004. Heightened activity was seen in mid-2015. Turla is known for conducting watering hole and spearphishing campaigns and leveraging in-house tools and malware. Turla’s espionage platform is mainly used against Windows machines, but has also been seen used against macOS and Linux machines. [1] [2] [3] [4]
Turla.Aliases: Turla, Waterbug, WhiteBear, VENOMOUS BEAR, Snake, Krypton

Techniques Used.Name: Brute Force
Techniques Used.Use: Turla may attempt to connect to systems within a victim's network using net use commands and a predefined list or collection of passwords.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: File and Directory Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover files in specific locations on the hard disk %TEMP% directory, the current user's desktop, and in the Program Files directory.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Indicator Removal from Tools
Techniques Used.Use: Based on comparison of Gazer versions, Turla made an effort to obfuscate strings in the malware that could be used as IoCs, including the mutex name and named pipe.[2]

Techniques Used.Name: PowerShell
Techniques Used.Use: Turla has used a custom executable to execute PowerShell scripts.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover running processes using the tasklist /v command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Injection
Techniques Used.Use: Turla has used Metasploit to perform reflective DLL injection in order to escalate privileges.[5][6]

Techniques Used.Name: Query Registry
Techniques Used.Use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover information in the Windows Registry with the reg query command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Techniques Used.Use: A Turla Javascript backdoor added a local_update_check value under the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to establish persistence. Additionally, a Turla custom executable containing Metasploit shellcode is saved to the Startup folder to gain persistence.[4][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote File Copy
Techniques Used.Use: Turla has used shellcode to download Meterpreter after compromising a victim.[5]

Techniques Used.Name: Remote System Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover remote systems on a local network using the net view and net view /DOMAIN commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Spearphishing Link
Techniques Used.Use: Turla attempted to trick targets into clicking on a link featuring a seemingly legitimate domain from Adobe.com to download their malware and gain initial access.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Techniques Used.Use: Turla has used HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.[4][5]

Techniques Used.Name: System Information Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover operating system configuration details using the systeminfo and set commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover network configuration details using the arp -a, nbtstat -n, and net config commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover active local network connections using the netstat -an, net use, net file, and net session commands.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Service Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover running services and associated processes using the tasklist /svc command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: System Time Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover the system time by using the net time command.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: User Execution
Techniques Used.Use: Turla has used spearphishing via a link to get users to download and run their malware.[4]

Techniques Used.Name: Web Service
Techniques Used.Use: A Turla JavaScript backdoor has used Google Apps Script as its C2 server.[4][5]

Techniques Used.Name: Windows Admin Shares
Techniques Used.Use: Turla used net use commands to connect to lateral systems within a network.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Winlogon Helper DLL
Techniques Used.Use: Turla established persistence by adding a Shell value under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion]Winlogon.[4]

Winnti Group.Name: Winnti Group
Winnti Group.Description: Winnti Group is a threat group with Chinese origins that has been active since at least 2010. The group has heavily targeted the gaming industry, but it has also expanded the scope of its targeting. [1] [2] [3] Some reporting suggests a number of other groups, including Axiom, APT17, and Ke3chang, are closely linked to Winnti Group. [4]

Techniques Used.Name: Code Signing
Techniques Used.Use: Winnti Group used stolen certificates to sign its malware.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Process Discovery
Techniques Used.Use: Winnti Group looked for a specific process running on infected servers.[1]

Techniques Used.Name: Rootkit
Techniques Used.Use: Winnti Group used a rootkit to modify typical server functionality.[1]
